an7.52:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggara Lotus Pond.
an7.52:4.2: Then many lay followers of Campā went to Venerable Sāriputta
an7.52:4.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
an7.52:4.5: “Sir, it’s been a long time since we’ve heard a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.
an7.52:4.6: It’d be good if we got to hear a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.”
an7.52:4.7: “Well then, reverends, come on the next sabbath day. Hopefully you’ll get to hear a Dhamma talk from the Buddha.”
an7.52:4.8: “Yes, sir” they replied. Then they rose from their seats, bowed to Sāriputta, and respectfully circled him before leaving.
an7.52:5.1: Then on the next sabbath the lay followers of Campā went to Venerable Sāriputta,
an7.52:5.2: bowed, and stood to one side.
an7.52:5.3: Then they went together with Sāriputta to the Buddha,
an7.52:5.4: bowed, and sat down to one side.
an7.52:6.1: “Sir, could it be that someone gives a gift and it is not very fruitful or beneficial,
an7.52:6.2: while someone else gives exactly the same gift and it is very fruitful and beneficial?”
an7.52:6.5: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason for this?”
an7.52:7.1: “Sāriputta, take the case of a someone who gives a gift as an investment, their mind tied to it, expecting to keep it, thinking ‘I’ll enjoy this in my next life’.
an7.52:7.2: They give to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, perfumes, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.
an7.52:7.3: What do you think, Sāriputta, don’t some people give gifts in this way?”
an7.52:8.1: “Sāriputta, someone who gives a gift as an investment,
an7.52:8.2: when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the gods of the Four Great Kings.
an7.52:8.3: When that deed, success, fame, and dominion is spent they return to this world.
an7.52:9.1: Next, take the case of a someone who gives a gift not as an investment, their mind not tied to it, not expecting to keep it, and not thinking ‘I’ll enjoy this in my next life’.
an7.52:9.2: But they give a gift thinking, ‘It’s good to give’ …
an7.52:10.2: They give a gift thinking, ‘Giving was practiced by my father and my father’s father. It would not be right for me to abandon this family tradition.’ …
an7.52:11.2: They give a gift thinking, ‘I cook, they don’t. It wouldn’t be right for me to not give to them.’ …
an7.52:12.2: They give a gift thinking, ‘The brahmin seers of the past were Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamadaggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu.
an7.52:12.3: Just as they performed great sacrifices, I will share a gift.” …
an7.52:13.3: They give a gift thinking, ‘When giving this gift my mind becomes clear, and I become happy and joyful.’
an7.52:14.1: They don’t give a gift thinking, ‘When giving this gift my mind becomes clear, and I become happy and joyful.’
an7.52:14.2: But they give a gift thinking, ‘This is an adornment and requisite for the mind.’
an7.52:14.3: They give to ascetics or brahmins such things as food, drink, clothing, vehicles; garlands, perfumes, and makeup; and bed, house, and lighting.
an7.52:14.4: What do you think, Sāriputta, don’t some people give gifts in this way?”
an7.52:15.1: “Sāriputta, someone who gives gifts, not for any other reason,
an7.52:15.11: but thinking, ‘This is an adornment and requisite for the mind’,
an7.52:15.12: when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the company of the Brahmā gods.
an7.52:15.13: When that deed, success, fame, and dominion is spent they return to this world.
an7.52:16.1: This is the cause, this is the reason why someone gives a gift and it is not very fruitful or beneficial,
an7.52:16.2: while someone else gives exactly the same gift and it is very fruitful and beneficial.”
